Sprint qualifying is essentially a short-form Grand Prix Â– a race that is one-third the number of laps of the main event on Sunday. However, the drivers are battling for positions on the grid for the start of Sundays race.',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying each race',

commonsense evidence: 
Q1 lap times determine pole position and the order of the front 10 positions on the grid. The slowest driver in Q1 starts 10th, the next starts ninth and so on.

commonsense evidence: 
only top 15 in the q1 has the record of q2

only top 10 in the q2 has the record of q3'

Sprint qualifying is essentially a short-form Grand Prix Â– a race that is one-third the number of laps of the main event on Sunday. However, the drivers are battling for positions on the grid for the start of Sundays race.',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying each race',

commonsense evidence: 
Q1 lap times determine pole position and the order of the front 10 positions on the grid. The slowest driver in Q1 starts 10th, the next starts ninth and so on.

only top 15 in the q1 has the record of q2

only top 10 in the q2 has the record of q3'

1. if the value exists, it means the driver finished the race. 
2. Only the time of the champion shows in the format of "minutes: seconds.millionsecond", the time of the other drivers shows as "seconds.millionsecond" , which means their actual time is the time of the champion adding the value in this cell.',
  `milliseconds` BIGINT COMMENT 'the actual finishing time of drivers in milliseconds; the actual finishing time of drivers',
  `fastestLap` BIGINT COMMENT 'fastest lap number',

  `statusId` BIGINT COMMENT 'status ID; its category description appear in the table status'
);

);
CREATE TABLE `status` (
  `statusId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying status',
  `status` TEXT COMMENT 'full name of status'
);

### ç¬¬äºŒéƒ¨åˆ†ï¼šæ‰¾å‡ºè¿™ä½å¸æœºé¦–æ¬¡å‚èµ›çš„æ¯”èµ›åç§°

#### æ–¹æ³•ä¸€ï¼šä½¿ç”¨å­æŸ¥è¯¢

```sql
SELECT d.forename, d.surname, d.nationality,
       r.name AS first_race_name
FROM drivers d
JOIN results res ON d.driverId = res.driverId
JOIN races r ON res.raceId = r.raceId
```

#### æ–¹æ³•äºŒï¼šæ›´æ¸…æ™°åœ°å…ˆé€‰å‡ºæœ€å¹´è½»çš„å¸æœºå†æŸ¥å…¶ç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡å‚èµ›

```sql
WITH youngest_driver AS (
    SELECT driverId, forename, surname, nationality
    FROM drivers
    WHERE dob = (SELECT MAX(dob) FROM drivers)
    LIMIT 1
),
first_race AS (
    SELECT r.name
    FROM results res
    JOIN races r ON res.raceId = r.raceId
    WHERE res.driverId = (SELECT driverId FROM youngest_driver)
    ORDER BY r.year ASC, r.round ASC
    LIMIT 1
)
SELECT y.forename, y.surname, y.nationality, f.name AS first_race_name
FROM youngest_driver y
CROSS JOIN first_race f;
```

WITH `fastest_lap_times` AS (
  SELECT
    `T1`.`raceId`,
    `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
    (
      CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, 1, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) * 60
    ) + (
      CAST(SUBSTR(
        `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
        INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') + 1,
        INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') - INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1
      ) AS DOUBLE)
    ) + (
      CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000
    ) AS `time_in_seconds`
  FROM `results` AS `T1`
  WHERE
    NOT `T1`.`FastestLapTime` IS NULL
)
SELECT
  `T1`.`FastestLapTime` AS `lap_record`
FROM `results` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
INNER JOIN `circuits` AS `T3`
  ON `T2`.`circuitId` = `T3`.`circuitId`
INNER JOIN (
  SELECT
    MIN(`fastest_lap_times`.`time_in_seconds`) AS `min_time_in_seconds`
  FROM `fastest_lap_times`
  INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
    ON `fastest_lap_times`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
  INNER JOIN `circuits` AS `T3`
    ON `T2`.`circuitId` = `T3`.`circuitId`
  WHERE
    `T3`.`country` = 'Italy'
) AS `T4`
  ON (
    CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, 1, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) * 60
  ) + (
    CAST(SUBSTR(
      `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
      INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') + 1,
      INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') - INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1
    ) AS DOUBLE)
  ) + (
    CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000
  ) = `T4`.`min_time_in_seconds`
LIMIT 1

CREATE TABLE `circuits` (
  `circuitId` BIGINT COMMENT 'unique identification number of the circuit',

  `country` TEXT COMMENT 'country of circuit',
  `lat` DOUBLE COMMENT 'latitude of location of circuit',
  `lng` DOUBLE COMMENT 'longitude of location of circuit; commonsense evidence: 
Location coordinates: (lat, lng)',
  `alt` BIGINT COMMENT 'not useful',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'url'
);

  `constructorResultsId` BIGINT COMMENT 'constructor Results Id',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'race id',
  `constructorId` BIGINT COMMENT 'constructor id',

  `status` TEXT COMMENT 'status'
);

  `points` TEXT COMMENT 'how many points acquired in each race',
  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'position or track of circuits',

  `wins` BIGINT COMMENT 'wins'
);

  `nationality` TEXT COMMENT 'nationality of the constructor',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'the introduction website of the constructor; commonsense evidence: 
How to find out the detailed introduction of the constructor: through its url',
  `wins` BIGINT COMMENT 'wins'
);
CREATE TABLE `driverStandings` (
  `driverStandingsId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying driver standing records',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'id number identifying which races',
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'id number identifying which drivers',
  `points` DOUBLE COMMENT 'how many points acquired in each race',
  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'position or track of circuits',
  `positionText` TEXT COMMENT 'same with position, not quite useful',
  `wins` BIGINT COMMENT 'wins'
);
CREATE TABLE `drivers` (
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying each driver',
  `driverRef` TEXT COMMENT 'driver reference name',
  `number` BIGINT COMMENT 'number',
  `code` TEXT COMMENT 'abbreviated code for drivers; if "null" or empty, it means it doesnt have code',
  `forename` TEXT COMMENT 'forename',
  `surname` TEXT COMMENT 'surname',
  `dob` TEXT COMMENT 'date of birth',
  `nationality` TEXT COMMENT 'nationality of drivers',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'the introduction website of the drivers'
);
CREATE TABLE `lapTimes` (
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying race',
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying each driver',
  `lap` BIGINT COMMENT 'lap number',
  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'position or track of circuits',
  `time` TEXT COMMENT 'lap time; in minutes / seconds / ...',
  `milliseconds` BIGINT COMMENT 'milliseconds'
);
CREATE TABLE `pitStops` (

  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying each driver',
  `stop` BIGINT COMMENT 'stop number',
  `lap` BIGINT COMMENT 'lap number',
  `time` TEXT COMMENT 'time; exact time',
  `duration` TEXT COMMENT 'duration time; seconds/',
  `milliseconds` BIGINT COMMENT 'milliseconds'
);
CREATE TABLE `qualifying` (
  `qualifyId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying qualifying; How does F1 Sprint qualifying work? Sprint qualifying is essentially a short-form Grand Prix Â– a race that is one-third the number of laps of the main event on Sunday. However, the drivers are battling for positions on the grid for the start of Sundays race.',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying each race',
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying each driver',
  `constructorId` BIGINT COMMENT 'constructor Id',
  `number` BIGINT COMMENT 'number',
  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'position or track of circuit',
  `q1` TEXT COMMENT 'time in qualifying 1; in minutes / seconds / ... 
commonsense evidence: 
Q1 lap times determine pole position and the order of the front 10 positions on the grid. The slowest driver in Q1 starts 10th, the next starts ninth and so on. 
All 20 F1 drivers participate in the first period, called Q1, with each trying to set the fastest time possible. Those in the top 15 move on to the next period of qualifying, called Q2. The five slowest drivers are eliminated and will start the race in the last five positions on the grid.',
  `q2` TEXT COMMENT 'time in qualifying 2; in minutes / seconds / ... 
commonsense evidence: 
only top 15 in the q1 has the record of q2 
Q2 is slightly shorter but follows the same format. Drivers try to put down their best times to move on to Q1 as one of the 10 fastest cars. The five outside of the top 10 are eliminated and start the race from 11th to 15th based on their best lap time.',
  `q3` TEXT COMMENT 'time in qualifying 3; in minutes / seconds / ... 
commonsense evidence: 
only top 10 in the q2 has the record of q3'
);
CREATE TABLE `races` (
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying the race',
  `year` BIGINT COMMENT 'year',
  `round` BIGINT COMMENT 'round',
  `circuitId` BIGINT COMMENT 'circuit Id',
  `name` TEXT COMMENT 'name of the race',
  `date` TEXT COMMENT 'duration time',
  `time` TEXT COMMENT 'time of the location',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'introduction of races'
);
CREATE TABLE `results` (
  `resultId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying race result',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying the race',
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying the driver',
  `constructorId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying which constructors',
  `number` BIGINT COMMENT 'number',
  `grid` BIGINT COMMENT 'the number identifying the area where cars are set into a grid formation in order to start the race.',
  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'The finishing position or track of circuits',
  `positionText` TEXT COMMENT 'not quite useful',
  `positionOrder` BIGINT COMMENT 'the finishing order of positions',
  `points` DOUBLE COMMENT 'points',
  `laps` BIGINT COMMENT 'lap number',
  `time` TEXT COMMENT 'finish time; commonsense evidence: 
1. if the value exists, it means the driver finished the race. 
2. Only the time of the champion shows in the format of "minutes: seconds.millionsecond", the time of the other drivers shows as "seconds.millionsecond" , which means their actual time is the time of the champion adding the value in this cell.',
  `milliseconds` BIGINT COMMENT 'the actual finishing time of drivers in milliseconds; the actual finishing time of drivers',
  `fastestLap` BIGINT COMMENT 'fastest lap number',
  `rank` BIGINT COMMENT 'starting rank positioned by fastest lap speed',
  `fastestLapTime` TEXT COMMENT 'fastest Lap Time; faster (smaller in the value) "fastestLapTime" leads to higher rank (smaller is higher rank)',
  `fastestLapSpeed` TEXT COMMENT 'fastest Lap Speed; (km / h)',
  `statusId` BIGINT COMMENT 'status ID; its category description appear in the table status'
);
CREATE TABLE `seasons` (
  `year` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying the race',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'website link of season race introduction'
);
CREATE TABLE `status` (
  `statusId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying status',
  `status` TEXT COMMENT 'full name of status'
);

WITH `fastest_lap_times` AS (
  SELECT
    `T1`.`raceId`,
    `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
    (
      CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, 1, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) * 60
    ) + (
      CAST(SUBSTR(
        `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
        INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') + 1,
        INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') - INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1
      ) AS DOUBLE)
    ) + (
      CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000
    ) AS `time_in_seconds`
  FROM `results` AS `T1`
  WHERE
    NOT `T1`.`FastestLapTime` IS NULL
)
SELECT
  `T1`.`FastestLapTime` AS `lap_record`
FROM `results` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
INNER JOIN `circuits` AS `T3`
  ON `T2`.`circuitId` = `T3`.`circuitId`
INNER JOIN (
  SELECT
    MIN(`fastest_lap_times`.`time_in_seconds`) AS `min_time_in_seconds`
  FROM `fastest_lap_times`
  INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
    ON `fastest_lap_times`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
  INNER JOIN `circuits` AS `T3`
    ON `T2`.`circuitId` = `T3`.`circuitId`
  WHERE
    `T3`.`country` = 'Italy'
) AS `T4`
  ON (
    CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, 1, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) * 60
  ) + (
    CAST(SUBSTR(
      `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
      INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') + 1,
      INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') - INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1
    ) AS DOUBLE)
  ) + (
    CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000
  ) = `T4`.`min_time_in_seconds`
LIMIT 1

```sql
SELECT 
    c.name AS circuit_name,

    d.forename,

WHERE c.country = 'Italy'
```
```sql
ORDER BY r.year, res.fastestLapTime;
```

WITH `fastest_lap_times` AS (
  SELECT
    `T1`.`raceId`,
    `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
    (
      CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, 1, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) * 60
    ) + (
      CAST(SUBSTR(
        `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
        INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') + 1,
        INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') - INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1
      ) AS DOUBLE)
    ) + (
      CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000
    ) AS `time_in_seconds`
  FROM `results` AS `T1`
  WHERE
    NOT `T1`.`FastestLapTime` IS NULL
)
SELECT
  `T1`.`FastestLapTime` AS `lap_record`
FROM `results` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
INNER JOIN `circuits` AS `T3`
  ON `T2`.`circuitId` = `T3`.`circuitId`
INNER JOIN (
  SELECT
    MIN(`fastest_lap_times`.`time_in_seconds`) AS `min_time_in_seconds`
  FROM `fastest_lap_times`
  INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
    ON `fastest_lap_times`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
  INNER JOIN `circuits` AS `T3`
    ON `T2`.`circuitId` = `T3`.`circuitId`
  WHERE
    `T3`.`country` = 'Italy'
) AS `T4`
  ON (
    CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, 1, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) * 60
  ) + (
    CAST(SUBSTR(
      `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
      INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') + 1,
      INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') - INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1
    ) AS DOUBLE)
  ) + (
    CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000
  ) = `T4`.`min_time_in_seconds`
LIMIT 1

CREATE TABLE `circuits` (
  `circuitId` BIGINT COMMENT 'unique identification number of the circuit',
  `circuitRef` TEXT COMMENT 'circuit reference name',
  `name` TEXT COMMENT 'full name of circuit',
  `location` TEXT COMMENT 'location of circuit',
  `country` TEXT COMMENT 'country of circuit',
  `lat` DOUBLE COMMENT 'latitude of location of circuit',
  `lng` DOUBLE COMMENT 'longitude of location of circuit; commonsense evidence: 
Location coordinates: (lat, lng)',
  `alt` BIGINT COMMENT 'not useful',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'url'
);
CREATE TABLE `constructorResults` (
  `constructorResultsId` BIGINT COMMENT 'constructor Results Id',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'race id',
  `constructorId` BIGINT COMMENT 'constructor id',
  `points` DOUBLE COMMENT 'points',
  `status` TEXT COMMENT 'status'
);
CREATE TABLE `constructorStandings` (
  `constructorStandingsId` BIGINT COMMENT 'unique identification of the constructor standing records',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'id number identifying which races',
  `constructorId` BIGINT COMMENT 'id number identifying which id',
  `points` TEXT COMMENT 'how many points acquired in each race',
  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'position or track of circuits',
  `positionText` TEXT COMMENT 'same with position, not quite useful',
  `wins` BIGINT COMMENT 'wins'
);
CREATE TABLE `constructors` (
  `constructorId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying constructors',
  `constructorRef` TEXT COMMENT 'Constructor Reference name',
  `name` TEXT COMMENT 'full name of the constructor',
  `nationality` TEXT COMMENT 'nationality of the constructor',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'the introduction website of the constructor; commonsense evidence: 
How to find out the detailed introduction of the constructor: through its url',
  `wins` BIGINT COMMENT 'wins'
);
CREATE TABLE `driverStandings` (
  `driverStandingsId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying driver standing records',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'id number identifying which races',
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'id number identifying which drivers',
  `points` DOUBLE COMMENT 'how many points acquired in each race',
  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'position or track of circuits',
  `positionText` TEXT COMMENT 'same with position, not quite useful',
  `wins` BIGINT COMMENT 'wins'
);
CREATE TABLE `drivers` (
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying each driver',
  `driverRef` TEXT COMMENT 'driver reference name',
  `number` BIGINT COMMENT 'number',
  `code` TEXT COMMENT 'abbreviated code for drivers; if "null" or empty, it means it doesnt have code',
  `forename` TEXT COMMENT 'forename',
  `surname` TEXT COMMENT 'surname',
  `dob` TEXT COMMENT 'date of birth',
  `nationality` TEXT COMMENT 'nationality of drivers',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'the introduction website of the drivers'
);
CREATE TABLE `lapTimes` (
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying race',
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying each driver',
  `lap` BIGINT COMMENT 'lap number',
  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'position or track of circuits',
  `time` TEXT COMMENT 'lap time; in minutes / seconds / ...',
  `milliseconds` BIGINT COMMENT 'milliseconds'
);
CREATE TABLE `pitStops` (
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying race',
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying each driver',
  `stop` BIGINT COMMENT 'stop number',
  `lap` BIGINT COMMENT 'lap number',
  `time` TEXT COMMENT 'time; exact time',
  `duration` TEXT COMMENT 'duration time; seconds/',
  `milliseconds` BIGINT COMMENT 'milliseconds'
);
CREATE TABLE `qualifying` (
  `qualifyId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying qualifying; How does F1 Sprint qualifying work? Sprint qualifying is essentially a short-form Grand Prix Â– a race that is one-third the number of laps of the main event on Sunday. However, the drivers are battling for positions on the grid for the start of Sundays race.',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying each race',
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying each driver',
  `constructorId` BIGINT COMMENT 'constructor Id',
  `number` BIGINT COMMENT 'number',
  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'position or track of circuit',
  `q1` TEXT COMMENT 'time in qualifying 1; in minutes / seconds / ... 
commonsense evidence: 
Q1 lap times determine pole position and the order of the front 10 positions on the grid. The slowest driver in Q1 starts 10th, the next starts ninth and so on. 
All 20 F1 drivers participate in the first period, called Q1, with each trying to set the fastest time possible. Those in the top 15 move on to the next period of qualifying, called Q2. The five slowest drivers are eliminated and will start the race in the last five positions on the grid.',
  `q2` TEXT COMMENT 'time in qualifying 2; in minutes / seconds / ... 
commonsense evidence: 
only top 15 in the q1 has the record of q2 
Q2 is slightly shorter but follows the same format. Drivers try to put down their best times to move on to Q1 as one of the 10 fastest cars. The five outside of the top 10 are eliminated and start the race from 11th to 15th based on their best lap time.',
  `q3` TEXT COMMENT 'time in qualifying 3; in minutes / seconds / ... 
commonsense evidence: 
only top 10 in the q2 has the record of q3'
);
CREATE TABLE `races` (
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying the race',
  `year` BIGINT COMMENT 'year',
  `round` BIGINT COMMENT 'round',
  `circuitId` BIGINT COMMENT 'circuit Id',
  `name` TEXT COMMENT 'name of the race',
  `date` TEXT COMMENT 'duration time',
  `time` TEXT COMMENT 'time of the location',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'introduction of races'
);
CREATE TABLE `results` (
  `resultId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying race result',
  `raceId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying the race',
  `driverId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying the driver',
  `constructorId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the identification number identifying which constructors',
  `number` BIGINT COMMENT 'number',
  `grid` BIGINT COMMENT 'the number identifying the area where cars are set into a grid formation in order to start the race.',
  `position` BIGINT COMMENT 'The finishing position or track of circuits',
  `positionText` TEXT COMMENT 'not quite useful',
  `positionOrder` BIGINT COMMENT 'the finishing order of positions',
  `points` DOUBLE COMMENT 'points',
  `laps` BIGINT COMMENT 'lap number',
  `time` TEXT COMMENT 'finish time; commonsense evidence: 
1. if the value exists, it means the driver finished the race. 
2. Only the time of the champion shows in the format of "minutes: seconds.millionsecond", the time of the other drivers shows as "seconds.millionsecond" , which means their actual time is the time of the champion adding the value in this cell.',
  `milliseconds` BIGINT COMMENT 'the actual finishing time of drivers in milliseconds; the actual finishing time of drivers',
  `fastestLap` BIGINT COMMENT 'fastest lap number',
  `rank` BIGINT COMMENT 'starting rank positioned by fastest lap speed',
  `fastestLapTime` TEXT COMMENT 'fastest Lap Time; faster (smaller in the value) "fastestLapTime" leads to higher rank (smaller is higher rank)',
  `fastestLapSpeed` TEXT COMMENT 'fastest Lap Speed; (km / h)',
  `statusId` BIGINT COMMENT 'status ID; its category description appear in the table status'
);
CREATE TABLE `seasons` (
  `year` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying the race',
  `url` TEXT COMMENT 'website link of season race introduction'
);
CREATE TABLE `status` (
  `statusId` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identification number identifying status',
  `status` TEXT COMMENT 'full name of status'
);

åœˆé€Ÿè®°å½•æ˜¯æŒ‡è®°å½•çš„æœ€å¿«æ—¶é—´ï¼ŒæŒ‡çš„æ˜¯æ—¶é—´

chosen:
WITH `fastest_lap_times` AS (
  SELECT
    `T1`.`raceId`,
    `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
    (
      CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, 1, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) * 60
    ) + (
      CAST(SUBSTR(
        `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
        INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') + 1,
        INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') - INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1
      ) AS DOUBLE)
    ) + (
      CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000
    ) AS `time_in_seconds`
  FROM `results` AS `T1`
  WHERE
    NOT `T1`.`FastestLapTime` IS NULL
)
SELECT
  `T1`.`FastestLapTime` AS `lap_record`
FROM `results` AS `T1`
INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
  ON `T1`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
INNER JOIN `circuits` AS `T3`
  ON `T2`.`circuitId` = `T3`.`circuitId`
INNER JOIN (
  SELECT
    MIN(`fastest_lap_times`.`time_in_seconds`) AS `min_time_in_seconds`
  FROM `fastest_lap_times`
  INNER JOIN `races` AS `T2`
    ON `fastest_lap_times`.`raceId` = `T2`.`raceId`
  INNER JOIN `circuits` AS `T3`
    ON `T2`.`circuitId` = `T3`.`circuitId`
  WHERE
    `T3`.`country` = 'Italy'
) AS `T4`
  ON (
    CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, 1, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1) AS DOUBLE) * 60
  ) + (
    CAST(SUBSTR(
      `T1`.`FastestLapTime`,
      INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') + 1,
      INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') - INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, ':') - 1
    ) AS DOUBLE)
  ) + (
    CAST(SUBSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, INSTR(`T1`.`FastestLapTime`, '.') + 1) AS DOUBLE) / 1000
  ) = `T4`.`min_time_in_seconds`
LIMIT 1

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.

);

For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'

  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',

The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',

Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.

);

);

);

);

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.
Â•	Bad: These superheroes are typically selfish, manipulative, and willing to harm others in pursuit of their own goals. Examples of evil alignments include Lex Luthor and the Joker.'
);
CREATE TABLE `attribute` (

);

Maps to superhero(id)',

Maps to attribute(id)',

If a superhero has a higher attribute value on a particular attribute, it means that they are more skilled or powerful in that area compared to other superheroes. For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_power` (

);
CREATE TABLE `publisher` (

  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',
  `eye_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros eye color',

  `skin_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros skin color',
  `race_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros race',
  `publisher_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the publisher',
  `alignment_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros alignment',
  `height_cm` BIGINT COMMENT 'the height of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of height is centimeter. If the height_cm is NULL or 0, it means the height of the superhero is missing.',
  `weight_kg` BIGINT COMMENT 'the weight of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);
CREATE TABLE `superpower` (

);

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',

Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.

);

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (

Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.

);

);

```sql
FROM hero_counts;
```

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.
Â•	Bad: These superheroes are typically selfish, manipulative, and willing to harm others in pursuit of their own goals. Examples of evil alignments include Lex Luthor and the Joker.'
);
CREATE TABLE `attribute` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the attribute',
  `attribute_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute; commonsense evidence:
A superheros attribute is a characteristic or quality that defines who they are and what they are capable of. This could be a physical trait, such as superhuman strength or the ability to fly, or a personal trait, such as extraordinary intelligence or exceptional bravery.'
);
CREATE TABLE `colour` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the color',
  `colour` TEXT COMMENT 'the color of the superheros skin/eye/hair/etc'
);
CREATE TABLE `gender` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the gender',
  `gender` TEXT COMMENT 'the gender of the superhero'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_attribute` (
  `hero_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `attribute_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the attribute
Maps to attribute(id)',
  `attribute_value` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute value; commonsense evidence:
If a superhero has a higher attribute value on a particular attribute, it means that they are more skilled or powerful in that area compared to other superheroes. For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_power` (
  `hero_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `power_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the power
Maps to superpower(id); commonsense evidence:
In general, a superheros attributes provide the foundation for their abilities and help to define who they are, while their powers are the specific abilities that they use to fight crime and protect others.'
);
CREATE TABLE `publisher` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the publisher',
  `publisher_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the publisher'
);
CREATE TABLE `race` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the race',
  `race` TEXT COMMENT 'the race of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
In the context of superheroes, a superheros race would refer to the particular group of people that the superhero belongs to base on these physical characteristics'
);
CREATE TABLE `superhero` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superhero',
  `superhero_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the superhero',
  `full_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the full name of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The full name of a person typically consists of their given name, also known as their first name or personal name, and their surname, also known as their last name or family name. For example, if someones given name is "John" and their surname is "Smith," their full name would be "John Smith."',
  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',
  `eye_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros eye color',
  `hair_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros hair color',
  `skin_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros skin color',
  `race_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros race',
  `publisher_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the publisher',
  `alignment_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros alignment',
  `height_cm` BIGINT COMMENT 'the height of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of height is centimeter. If the height_cm is NULL or 0, it means the height of the superhero is missing.',
  `weight_kg` BIGINT COMMENT 'the weight of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);
CREATE TABLE `superpower` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superpower',
  `power_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the superpower name'
);

Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.
Â•	Bad: These superheroes are typically selfish, manipulative, and willing to harm others in pursuit of their own goals. Examples of evil alignments include Lex Luthor and the Joker.'
);
CREATE TABLE `attribute` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the attribute',
  `attribute_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute; commonsense evidence:
A superheros attribute is a characteristic or quality that defines who they are and what they are capable of. This could be a physical trait, such as superhuman strength or the ability to fly, or a personal trait, such as extraordinary intelligence or exceptional bravery.'
);
CREATE TABLE `colour` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the color',
  `colour` TEXT COMMENT 'the color of the superheros skin/eye/hair/etc'
);
CREATE TABLE `gender` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the gender',
  `gender` TEXT COMMENT 'the gender of the superhero'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_attribute` (
  `hero_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `attribute_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the attribute
Maps to attribute(id)',
  `attribute_value` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute value; commonsense evidence:
If a superhero has a higher attribute value on a particular attribute, it means that they are more skilled or powerful in that area compared to other superheroes. For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_power` (
  `hero_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `power_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the power
Maps to superpower(id); commonsense evidence:
In general, a superheros attributes provide the foundation for their abilities and help to define who they are, while their powers are the specific abilities that they use to fight crime and protect others.'
);
CREATE TABLE `publisher` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the publisher',
  `publisher_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the publisher'
);
CREATE TABLE `race` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the race',
  `race` TEXT COMMENT 'the race of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
In the context of superheroes, a superheros race would refer to the particular group of people that the superhero belongs to base on these physical characteristics'
);
CREATE TABLE `superhero` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superhero',
  `superhero_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the superhero',
  `full_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the full name of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The full name of a person typically consists of their given name, also known as their first name or personal name, and their surname, also known as their last name or family name. For example, if someones given name is "John" and their surname is "Smith," their full name would be "John Smith."',
  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',
  `eye_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros eye color',
  `hair_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros hair color',
  `skin_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros skin color',
  `race_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros race',
  `publisher_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the publisher',
  `alignment_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros alignment',
  `height_cm` BIGINT COMMENT 'the height of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of height is centimeter. If the height_cm is NULL or 0, it means the height of the superhero is missing.',
  `weight_kg` BIGINT COMMENT 'the weight of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);
CREATE TABLE `superpower` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superpower',
  `power_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the superpower name'
);

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.
Â•	Bad: These superheroes are typically selfish, manipulative, and willing to harm others in pursuit of their own goals. Examples of evil alignments include Lex Luthor and the Joker.'
);
CREATE TABLE `attribute` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the attribute',
  `attribute_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute; commonsense evidence:
A superheros attribute is a characteristic or quality that defines who they are and what they are capable of. This could be a physical trait, such as superhuman strength or the ability to fly, or a personal trait, such as extraordinary intelligence or exceptional bravery.'
);
CREATE TABLE `colour` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the color',
  `colour` TEXT COMMENT 'the color of the superheros skin/eye/hair/etc'
);
CREATE TABLE `gender` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the gender',
  `gender` TEXT COMMENT 'the gender of the superhero'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_attribute` (
  `hero_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `attribute_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the attribute
Maps to attribute(id)',
  `attribute_value` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute value; commonsense evidence:
If a superhero has a higher attribute value on a particular attribute, it means that they are more skilled or powerful in that area compared to other superheroes. For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_power` (
  `hero_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `power_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the power
Maps to superpower(id); commonsense evidence:
In general, a superheros attributes provide the foundation for their abilities and help to define who they are, while their powers are the specific abilities that they use to fight crime and protect others.'
);
CREATE TABLE `publisher` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the publisher',
  `publisher_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the publisher'
);
CREATE TABLE `race` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the race',
  `race` TEXT COMMENT 'the race of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
In the context of superheroes, a superheros race would refer to the particular group of people that the superhero belongs to base on these physical characteristics'
);
CREATE TABLE `superhero` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superhero',
  `superhero_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the superhero',
  `full_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the full name of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The full name of a person typically consists of their given name, also known as their first name or personal name, and their surname, also known as their last name or family name. For example, if someones given name is "John" and their surname is "Smith," their full name would be "John Smith."',
  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',
  `eye_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros eye color',
  `hair_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros hair color',
  `skin_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros skin color',
  `race_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros race',
  `publisher_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the publisher',
  `alignment_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros alignment',
  `height_cm` BIGINT COMMENT 'the height of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of height is centimeter. If the height_cm is NULL or 0, it means the height of the superhero is missing.',
  `weight_kg` BIGINT COMMENT 'the weight of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);
CREATE TABLE `superpower` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superpower',
  `power_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the superpower name'
);

Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.
Â•	Bad: These superheroes are typically selfish, manipulative, and willing to harm others in pursuit of their own goals. Examples of evil alignments include Lex Luthor and the Joker.'
);
CREATE TABLE `attribute` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the attribute',
  `attribute_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute; commonsense evidence:
A superheros attribute is a characteristic or quality that defines who they are and what they are capable of. This could be a physical trait, such as superhuman strength or the ability to fly, or a personal trait, such as extraordinary intelligence or exceptional bravery.'
);
CREATE TABLE `colour` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the color',
  `colour` TEXT COMMENT 'the color of the superheros skin/eye/hair/etc'
);
CREATE TABLE `gender` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the gender',
  `gender` TEXT COMMENT 'the gender of the superhero'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_attribute` (
  `hero_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `attribute_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the attribute
Maps to attribute(id)',
  `attribute_value` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute value; commonsense evidence:
If a superhero has a higher attribute value on a particular attribute, it means that they are more skilled or powerful in that area compared to other superheroes. For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_power` (
  `hero_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `power_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the power
Maps to superpower(id); commonsense evidence:
In general, a superheros attributes provide the foundation for their abilities and help to define who they are, while their powers are the specific abilities that they use to fight crime and protect others.'
);
CREATE TABLE `publisher` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the publisher',
  `publisher_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the publisher'
);
CREATE TABLE `race` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the race',
  `race` TEXT COMMENT 'the race of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
In the context of superheroes, a superheros race would refer to the particular group of people that the superhero belongs to base on these physical characteristics'
);
CREATE TABLE `superhero` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superhero',
  `superhero_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the superhero',
  `full_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the full name of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The full name of a person typically consists of their given name, also known as their first name or personal name, and their surname, also known as their last name or family name. For example, if someones given name is "John" and their surname is "Smith," their full name would be "John Smith."',
  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',
  `eye_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros eye color',
  `hair_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros hair color',
  `skin_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros skin color',
  `race_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros race',
  `publisher_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the publisher',
  `alignment_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros alignment',
  `height_cm` BIGINT COMMENT 'the height of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of height is centimeter. If the height_cm is NULL or 0, it means the height of the superhero is missing.',
  `weight_kg` BIGINT COMMENT 'the weight of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);
CREATE TABLE `superpower` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superpower',
  `power_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the superpower name'
);

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.
Â•	Bad: These superheroes are typically selfish, manipulative, and willing to harm others in pursuit of their own goals. Examples of evil alignments include Lex Luthor and the Joker.'
);
CREATE TABLE `attribute` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the attribute',
  `attribute_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute; commonsense evidence:
A superheros attribute is a characteristic or quality that defines who they are and what they are capable of. This could be a physical trait, such as superhuman strength or the ability to fly, or a personal trait, such as extraordinary intelligence or exceptional bravery.'
);
CREATE TABLE `colour` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the color',
  `colour` TEXT COMMENT 'the color of the superheros skin/eye/hair/etc'
);
CREATE TABLE `gender` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the gender',
  `gender` TEXT COMMENT 'the gender of the superhero'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_attribute` (
  `hero_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `attribute_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the attribute
Maps to attribute(id)',
  `attribute_value` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute value; commonsense evidence:
If a superhero has a higher attribute value on a particular attribute, it means that they are more skilled or powerful in that area compared to other superheroes. For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_power` (
  `hero_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `power_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the power
Maps to superpower(id); commonsense evidence:
In general, a superheros attributes provide the foundation for their abilities and help to define who they are, while their powers are the specific abilities that they use to fight crime and protect others.'
);
CREATE TABLE `publisher` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the publisher',
  `publisher_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the publisher'
);
CREATE TABLE `race` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the race',
  `race` TEXT COMMENT 'the race of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
In the context of superheroes, a superheros race would refer to the particular group of people that the superhero belongs to base on these physical characteristics'
);
CREATE TABLE `superhero` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superhero',
  `superhero_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the superhero',
  `full_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the full name of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The full name of a person typically consists of their given name, also known as their first name or personal name, and their surname, also known as their last name or family name. For example, if someones given name is "John" and their surname is "Smith," their full name would be "John Smith."',
  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',
  `eye_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros eye color',
  `hair_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros hair color',
  `skin_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros skin color',
  `race_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros race',
  `publisher_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the publisher',
  `alignment_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros alignment',
  `height_cm` BIGINT COMMENT 'the height of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of height is centimeter. If the height_cm is NULL or 0, it means the height of the superhero is missing.',
  `weight_kg` BIGINT COMMENT 'the weight of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);
CREATE TABLE `superpower` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superpower',
  `power_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the superpower name'
);

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.
Â•	Bad: These superheroes are typically selfish, manipulative, and willing to harm others in pursuit of their own goals. Examples of evil alignments include Lex Luthor and the Joker.'
);

A superheros attribute is a characteristic or quality that defines who they are and what they are capable of. This could be a physical trait, such as superhuman strength or the ability to fly, or a personal trait, such as extraordinary intelligence or exceptional bravery.'
);

Maps to superhero(id)',

Maps to attribute(id)',

If a superhero has a higher attribute value on a particular attribute, it means that they are more skilled or powerful in that area compared to other superheroes. For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'
);

In general, a superheros attributes provide the foundation for their abilities and help to define who they are, while their powers are the specific abilities that they use to fight crime and protect others.'

The unit of height is centimeter. If the height_cm is NULL or 0, it means the height of the superhero is missing.',
  `weight_kg` BIGINT COMMENT 'the weight of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);

  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superpower',

);

Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.

);

);

);

  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',
  `eye_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros eye color',
  `hair_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros hair color',
  `skin_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros skin color',
  `race_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros race',
  `publisher_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the publisher',

  `height_cm` BIGINT COMMENT 'the height of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of height is centimeter. If the height_cm is NULL or 0, it means the height of the superhero is missing.',
  `weight_kg` BIGINT COMMENT 'the weight of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);
CREATE TABLE `superpower` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superpower',
  `power_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the superpower name'
);

Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.

CREATE TABLE `alignment` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the alignment',
  `alignment` TEXT COMMENT 'the alignment of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
Alignment refers to a characters moral and ethical stance and can be used to describe the overall attitude or behavior of a superhero. Some common alignments for superheroes include:
Good: These superheroes are typically kind, selfless, and dedicated to protecting others and upholding justice. Examples of good alignments include Superman, Wonder Woman, and Spider-Man.
Neutral: These superheroes may not always prioritize the greater good, but they are not necessarily evil either. They may act in their own self-interest or make decisions based on their own moral code. Examples of neutral alignments include the Hulk and Deadpool.
Â•	Bad: These superheroes are typically selfish, manipulative, and willing to harm others in pursuit of their own goals. Examples of evil alignments include Lex Luthor and the Joker.'
);
CREATE TABLE `attribute` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the attribute',
  `attribute_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute; commonsense evidence:
A superheros attribute is a characteristic or quality that defines who they are and what they are capable of. This could be a physical trait, such as superhuman strength or the ability to fly, or a personal trait, such as extraordinary intelligence or exceptional bravery.'
);
CREATE TABLE `colour` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the color',
  `colour` TEXT COMMENT 'the color of the superheros skin/eye/hair/etc'
);
CREATE TABLE `gender` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the gender',
  `gender` TEXT COMMENT 'the gender of the superhero'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_attribute` (
  `hero_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `attribute_id` TEXT COMMENT 'the id of the attribute
Maps to attribute(id)',
  `attribute_value` TEXT COMMENT 'the attribute value; commonsense evidence:
If a superhero has a higher attribute value on a particular attribute, it means that they are more skilled or powerful in that area compared to other superheroes. For example, if a superhero has a higher attribute value for strength, they may be able to lift heavier objects or deliver more powerful punches than other superheroes.'
);
CREATE TABLE `hero_power` (
  `hero_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the hero
Maps to superhero(id)',
  `power_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the power
Maps to superpower(id); commonsense evidence:
In general, a superheros attributes provide the foundation for their abilities and help to define who they are, while their powers are the specific abilities that they use to fight crime and protect others.'
);
CREATE TABLE `publisher` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the publisher',
  `publisher_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the name of the publisher'
);
CREATE TABLE `race` (

In the context of superheroes, a superheros race would refer to the particular group of people that the superhero belongs to base on these physical characteristics'
);
CREATE TABLE `superhero` (

The full name of a person typically consists of their given name, also known as their first name or personal name, and their surname, also known as their last name or family name. For example, if someones given name is "John" and their surname is "Smith," their full name would be "John Smith."',
  `gender_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros gender',
  `eye_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros eye color',
  `hair_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros hair color',
  `skin_colour_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros skin color',
  `race_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros race',
  `publisher_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the publisher',
  `alignment_id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the id of the superheros alignment',
  `height_cm` BIGINT COMMENT 'the height of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of height is centimeter. If the height_cm is NULL or 0, it means the height of the superhero is missing.',
  `weight_kg` BIGINT COMMENT 'the weight of the superhero; commonsense evidence:
The unit of weight is kilogram. If the weight_kg is NULL or 0, it means the weight of the superhero is missing.'
);
CREATE TABLE `superpower` (
  `id` BIGINT COMMENT 'the unique identifier of the superpower',
  `power_name` TEXT COMMENT 'the superpower name'
);
